column1: [SAK-2272] Term "Assignment" refers to two different tools
column6:
Two completely separate tools in Sakai both use the term "Assignment" - the "Gradebook" tool and the "Assignment" tool. This is confusing. This will be even more confusing if the two tools ever communicate with each other.

It seems to make more sense that the Assignment tool keep the word "assignment" (being a tool where students can actually submit assignments) and the gradebook use some other term - this makes even more sense if the gradebook is to be made more flexible in the future and allow tracking of information like "attendance" or "participation" - things that students may be graded on but are not technically "assignments".

Current references to "assignment" in the gradebook should be changed to something more generic ("column", "item", "assessment", maybe something else entirely). I favor "item" as the most generic.
column10: Term "Assignment" refers to two different tools
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
Since Tests and Quizzes creates "Assessments" and communicates with Gradebook, that would be a more sensible word. If "the two tools[, Gradebook and Assignemnt Tool] ever communicate with each other" it would make sense to consider assessments, quizzes and tests to be forms of "assessment"--gradable things, in other words.

In the QTI world, assessments are used for tests and quizzes. I don't like "item" because in the pre-2.0 world it meant "question"(post 2.0 it is called"assessmentItem").
column45:
Just to be clear, I'm talking about the use of "assignment" in the user interface, not the code. In the user interface, there is context that helps define the meaning of a term if the term is generic, in the same way that a pronoun is defined by its antecedent. So if you add an "item" while on the quiz page, it's a quiz item (aka question), but if you add an item in the gradebook, it's a gradebook item. The term is loose enough to linguistically require the context for definition.

The problem with "assignment" is that it is too specific; there is no expectation that the meaning will shift depending on the context. "Assessment" is better, but it is still somewhat specific (are students really "assessed" on their attendance, or do they simply meet a minimum requirement?).

I think another reason I tend to favor "item" is that in actual use, gradebooks don't just contain grades. Given the flexibility, an instructor will use the gradebook as a place for recording other forms of information about the students. WebCT has this flexibility, and the gradebook is often used to record course section, student groups, seating charts, "response system" clicker IDs, etc, and these are sometimes used in the "selective release" function of WebCT but never as grades. The same is true of paper rosters or Excel spreadsheets. Sakai can't be used that flexibly (yet) but people will want that and eventually ask for it.

"Entry" is another possible choice, more specific than "item" but in a way that is appropriate for a gradebook or student record.
column49:
This issue duplicates SAK-1681 Closed . See further discussion there.

Briefly, "item" by itself is probably too generic. One major future requirement on the gradebook is the ability to group, weight etc by category. At first glance, entry seems better, but I wonder if that suggests "enter score." Among the generic possibilities, column seems best to me so far.

The problem of how to handle extra student metadata without making a mess of the UI is an interesting one. Between categories, non-enterprise student metadata and what we now call assignments, how many ways will there be to add columns? in which views are they represented? do all have to be combined into a single view?

Ben Brophy, the gradebook designer, has suggested that recording attendance may be better treated as a separate tool that communicates with the GB.

We need the new requirements process in place ASAP!
column75:
This is always a tricky area, especially when you consider that tools go by different names at different schools. At MIT we plan to use the Gradebook and call it that, but we have no plans to use the Assignment tool, favoring our own Homework tool in it's place. Also, we allow instructors to relabel their tools. So in some cases a class may call it's Homework/Assignment tool "Problem Sets" and it's Gradebook tool "Feedback." This doesn't effect the precise area of the UI mentioned in this suggestion, but keep in mind the flexibility of labels.

Now on to the "assignment" label...

In designing the UI for the gradebook we conducted series of usability test using a prototype (though not in the context of the assignments tool). We gave them the UI and the syllabus of a pretend class and asked them to talk us through how they would set it up, using the prototype. We tried both 'assessment' and 'item' in the UI and found that they lead to confusion. When using Item and to a lesser extent Assessment people weren't sure if that link would do what they needed. When we switched to Assignment, that problem dropped away.

I'm not saying that means we've found the solution and shouldn't change. But I do propose that the change be made on the basis of further usability testing. We'll be doing a round of testing this Fall on the live gradebook tool. We'll share the results and the protocol, and would love to see results from other schools.
column80: Closing, see the duplicate SAK-1681 Closed

column1: [SAK-2271] Send grades from Assignment tool to Gradebook tool
column6:
Gradebook should reflect all the grades that a student receives, the student should not need to check different pages for grades simply because the Sakai tools cannot talk to each other.

Creating a new Assignment in the Assignment tool should create a corresponding entry in the gradebook tool, and grading done in the Assignment tool should be sent automatically to the gradebook. Currently instructors need to do the grading in one tool (or offline), then manually create a new item in the gradebook and enter the data themselves.
column10: Send grades from Assignment tool to Gradebook tool
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: The Gradebook currently handles only points-based assignments. The Assignment tool readily supports multiple grade types because it doesn't do any calculations. In the short term, the assignments tool UI would need to change to export grades and reflect that only point based assignments can be submitted to GB. In the longer term, the GB will be required to support multiple grade types.
column45:
Grades which are using point values are not being copied into the gradebook. Instructors create the assignment and choose point based. They then grade the assignment and enter the grades in the assignment tool. The grades are not actually displayed in the gradebook at this point. They are only shown in the assignments tool and the gradebook displays an assignment with no grades shown.

Is this something that does not work in 2.0.1?
column49: As of 2.1.0 Assignment and Gradebook do not communicate with each other. Grades from the Assignment tool will not appear in the Gradebook. This feature request seeks to have that functionality implemented.
column75:
Can we upgrade this to major?
-AZ
column80:
I am working on the assignment integration with gradebook now. I need some feedback about UI design.

The following discussion applies to point-based assignment only.

Do we need any UI item at all for the integration? If not, Assignment tool can detect the existance of Gradebook tool, so that whenever an assignment is added/edited, it will create/update an entry in Gradebook. Later, whenever an submission is graded, the grade will be added into gradebook.

Or we do need some extra settings for this. We could add
1) a setting to Assignment object for adding grades to Gradebook, like Test & Quizzes does; Later the grade update will be automatic.
or
2) a "Add Grades to Gradebook" button in the list all submissions for an assignment view, next to the "Download All" button. User needs to click it to synchronize the grades in Gradebook with those in Assignment tool.

Suggestions? Comments?

Thanks,

  • Zhen
column84:
I would go with option 1 - a setting for the Assignment object for adding grades to gradebook. This would provide the automatic updating that instructors will expect, and also allow for non-graded use of the assignment tool (extra credit, practice or iterative assignments, etc).

A common example is assigning a term paper. Often the instructor will ask for a outline to be turned in by a certain date, followed by a list of references, followed by a draft, and ending with the final paper. Only the final paper is graded, so only that "assignment" should be added to the gradebook.
column88:
Checked in the first phase of integration, r4889, following the option 1 route.

Please let me know of any questions.

  • Zhen
column92:
I saw my change to this issue has been included in the 2.1.2 builds. I will mark this issue as resolved now for it to get into QA.

Only integration of point-based assignment is supported now. Extending to multiple scales is beyond 2.1.2 timeframe and need to be reported as a feature request in a separate JIRA item.

thanks,

  • Zhen
column96: assignment tool can auto insert point grade assignments into the gradebook now.

column1: [SAK-2270] Expand all and collapse all, or expand/open selected boxes
column6:
Currently the dropboxes default to all closed, many of our users have requested a way to open and close all of the dropboxes at once instead of clicking on each link individually. A more flexible approach would be to give each dropbox a checkbox then have "expand selected" and "close selected" items, along with a "select all".

The need for this feature is aggravated by the inability to see whether there are new items in the dropboxes unless you open them all first (see SAK-771 Closed and SAK-2269 Closed )

And if SAK-2269 Closed is implemented, it would be possible to have a "select new" item that would place checkmarks next to dropboxes with new items, making a "expand selected" item even more useful.
column10: Expand all and collapse all, or expand/open selected boxes
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: The current behavior at the head of sakai is that the twiggle to expand all/collapse all DOES open/close all of the folders. This was probably fixed after the 2.0.1 release. It doesn't do everything requested here, but it is an improvement.
column45:
I would say that I feel like an idiot for not seeing that, but I've read too much of Don Norman's writings.

"Expand/collapse All" does work in 2.01, and now that I see the twiggle, in hindsight it's easy to use, readily accessible, and makes sense. But without hindsight, it's not clear why the twiggle is where it is (next to the word "Title" in the row for sorting, rather than next to the top-level of the folder structure), and so not clear what it is meant to do and easily missed. The mapping is all wrong.

This feature request should be changed to clarify the "expand all" option by moving it down to the line that reads "Site Name Drop Box" or to explicitly state "expand all" to avoid confusion (the other identical black triangles only expand the item that they are pointing at), as well as to implement an "expand selected" feature as I described above.
column49: Dropbox currently includes an expand all/collapse feature.
column75: Joseph, if there is still something you would like to put forth as a feature request here, I'm afraid its getting lost in the noise, please feel to open a new issue to capture what that request is.

column1: [SAK-2269] New item notifications
column6:
Currently the dropbox has no method of indicating when an item has been added to the dropbox. There is a separate bug filed for having the date indicate the "modification date" of the folder SAK-771 Closed but that is just a partial solution.

The problem is that in a large class there is no easy way for an instructor to tell which students have uploaded material to their dropboxes. We have faculty who initially like the dropboxes call them "useless" because of this. Changing the date would allow the instructor to sort the most recent items first; that helps but leaves it up to the instructor to remember when they last accessed the dropboxes.

The dropbox would be more useful if it had active notifications of new items. Possibilities include:

  • e-mail notification sent to the instructor (as a value that a student could select, like what is done with resources), likewise a notification sent to the dropbox owner when a maintainer adds material.
  • A "new" flag that appears next to dropboxes that have items added since the last time the maintain account accessed the dropboxes. Ideally the "new" flag would appear next to both the folder and the new item.
  • A "hide" feature that would hide or show older items, leaving just the new items on the page.

All of this requires that Sakai track when an account looked at the dropboxes so it could distinguish what is "new" versus "old" with respect to that user. Doing it with respect to the login date won't work because the user may not have gone to the dropboxes during that session, in which case the content should still appear "new" the next time they log in.
column10: New item notifications
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
Several Michigan users have also requested a notification option that is sent to the student & instructor when a new item is added to the Drop Box.

This was a highly requested item in Michigan's Winter 2006 user survey (1,357 instructors & 2,485 students).
column45: Duplicate of SAK-8056--Has been combined with 8056.

column1: [SAK-2376] When RWiki is added to a site, Home page permissions are hardcoded

This template would contain everything about the page including all page permissions.

column1: [SAK-2267] MC answer choices not randomized for each student
column6:
Observed in all 3 nightly qa instances. I'm pretty sure this is a regression bug, as I'd checked for it before.

When you create a multiple choice question and select the "randomize answers" button, the answer choices should be randomized separately for each student who takes the assessment.

Instead, they seem to get randomized once and are the same for each student.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a multiple choice question. Give it 5 possible answers (Name them something obvious, like A through E) and choose the randomize option.

2. Add the question to an assessment and publish it.

3. Take the assessment as a student; when you get to the mc question, note down the order of the answer choices. (ie, what was ABCDE in question creation might now be randomized to BDCAE.)

4. Take the assessment again as a different student. When you get to the mc question, note the answer choices - are they exactly the same as they were for student 1? They shouldn't be.

Will check matching questions next.

column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: Nope, it's just multiple choice questions that have the problem. Matching question answer choices are properly randomized on all three instances.

column1: [SAK-2252] mysql feedback component settings are wonky

If you uncheck feedback components in the settings of core assessments, they may recheck themselves when you publish the assessment. This only happens on the mysql instance, and it's not consistent.

#1 - unchecked Statistics feedback component, published assessment
Result: Stats component was rechecked in the published assessment settings.

Result: Selection-level fb was rechecked, Stats wasn't.

#3 - unchecked all feedback components, published assessment.
Result: All components except Stats were rechecked.

When this happens it does not seem to affect the assessment in delivery. If you uncheck component X and it gets rechecked when you publish the assessment, component X will still not be visible to the student even though the settings for the published assessment say it should be.

column1: [SAK-2250] When replacing a file in resources, the old filename is retained
column6: When a user edits an item in resources, and replaces the file, Sakai retains the original filename. This is causing confusion for our users (who often append dates or initials to filenames to help keep track of versions).
column10: When replacing a file in resources, the old filename is retained
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
Dave, currently Sakai does not change the "Title" of a Resource to match the name of the file being uploaded as the replacement. A user, however, can edit the Title field on that same page, if desired. So, is the problem your describing that after the user edits the Title field the changes are ignored, or that the user expects simply selecting a new file to also change the Title?

If it is the former than we've got a bug. If it is the latter, however, then this is really a feature request. The desire to keep the Title the same, even when the uploaded filename was different, was selected by consensus the last time this issue came up. (See SAK-7863 Closed for related user-confusion over the difference between a Resource's Title, the name of the file being uploaded, and the Resources's URL.)
column45: Dave, I haven't heard anything further on this, so I'm going to presume that the Feature Request interpretation is correct.
column49:
ooops! I must have passed over the notification of your first comment.

From what I gather, the issue involved the url of the resource. They expected the url to change when they replaced the file. So basically they want the ID to change when you replace a file. Sounds like this has already been decided though, right?
column75: Decided for this release, but still open as a feature request to be revisited for a future release (along with the other related issues that have been cropping up.)
column80:
This should be categorized as a bug, not a feature request. Scenario steps:

1. Post a file called "Test.doc"
– Title = "Test.doc"
– Current File Name = "Test.doc"
– (This is correct behavior)
– Download URL is http://sakai.ucla.edu/access/content/group/0b857467-5fa2-4870-008b-cedac393ca31/Test.doc

2. Revise Properties and change uploaded file to "Test_2007.pdf"
– Title = "Test.doc" (But user can edit this, so this is an acceptable behavior)
– Current File Name = "Test.doc" (Should reflect the new uploaded file name of "Test_2007.pdf". User cannot edit this.)
– Download URL remains http://sakai.ucla.edu/access/content/group/0b857467-5fa2-4870-008b-cedac393ca31/Test.doc

This is the bug. The Current File Name and URL should match the new uploaded file name.

column1: [SAK-2249] Attachments to assignment submissions should go to dropbox
column6: We need to add back the ability to add a local file using the file picker. This need comes from a meeting I had with a faculty member last week. She uses the local file feature in the file picker to return graded assignments to students in the Assignments tool. As you can imagine, users do not want graded assignments to appear in the Resources area of a site for all to see. If you need UI for this, let me know, but I'm assuming we can just add what we had before. Thanks!
column10: Attachments to assignment submissions should go to dropbox
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
There is a significant design decision, more about the service, rather than the UI. The way this was done before was to make attachments totally public. They were placed in an "obscure" place, but anyone who had a URL could retrieve *ANY* attachment. It's probably not a good idea to handle graded student assignments that way either.

We can do this as you requested, but that opens a huge security issue. Doing it the right way depends on implementation of finer-grained permissions that allow a site maintainer to grant permissions within a folder on a single resource. Once that is done, we could then have the file-picker make that grant at the time a resource was added in a particular context that is open to just a few people.

All that said, I wonder if there's a work-around. Could the instructor upload the local file into the student's dropbox for the course through the new file picker? If so, does that give the right permissions so the student and the instructor (and nobody else) can see the file?
column45:
The temporary work-around is that instructors AND students should put attachments to students' submissions into the student's dropbox within the course site. This assigns the best permissions to the attachments. Both student and instructor should be able to see them, while other students will not. Attachments to assignments should go into the resources folder for the course site (so everyone in the site can view them).

The fix for this is that the assignments tool needs to be able to tell the file picker the default location for the uploaded attachment. If it is an attachment to an assignment, the attachment picker should guide the instructor to the site resources folder. If it is an attachment to a submission, the attachment picker should guide the user (student or instructor) to the individual dropbox.

If the dropbox tool does not exist in this site, there may be no dropbox channel. In that case, the dropbox channel should be created.
column49: This is close to what we discussed. There will be problems if anybody puts an attachment in a location where other parties can't see it. For example, if a student submits a paper and leaves it in "MyWorkspace Resources", instructor won't see it. But that problem can already occur if instructors attach resources and leave them in their own workspace, etc.
column75: This work was completed, but it was backed out later in favor of a different approach to dealing with attachments. The ticket for that work is SAK-2324 Closed . There is no way to verify SAK-2249 Closed since it is not actually part of the release.
column80: SAK-2324 Closed makes SAK-2249 Closed irrelevant.

column1: [SAK-2248] Navigating with Browser back-arrow
column6:
This has been noted elsewhere - SAK-251 Closed , for example - but since that issue was apparently more particular and then closed in a 1.5 audit back in the Spring, I didn't want to confuse things by reopening it. Instead, I'm creating this new one.

One of the chief interface complaints we're getting from students and faculty in our pilot is how the back arrow delivers mixed results. The back arrow will govern navigation between tools and sites, but not successive pages within the workflow of a tool. Consequences for these uneven results range from perplexed users to unwelcome tool locks.

We've urged users to use native Sakai navigation for now, but as things stand this is a failure to present intuitive navigation.

That should not, however, diminish the importance of this issue, as the requested functionality trips up almost everyone who uses Sakai at some point. Lots of folks have asked for it.

column1: [SAK-2242] Error message needed when session times out
column6:
An error message needs to be displayed if a user attempts to submit an assessment when a session times out that lets them know their information was lost and that their session has timed out. Currently users get a blank screen

To replicate
1) take assessment, stay idle 30 mins (sakai default)
2) click submit for grading
3) You should see a blank screen
column10: Error message needed when session times out
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: Marc, can you provide spec for this?
column45: Page 17 of delivery.051006.pdf has this warning message, though it should be "Assessments" rather than "My Assessments".
column49:
As a interim solution, Jarrod@IU has implemented this work around (see email below). Anyway, we still need a general session time out procedure from sakai so users knows what is going on. I alraedy email Glenn and am waiting for his reply.

Daisy

>>>>>

Sure, have a look at SessionUtil. I'm currently setting the timeout to either (the time of the timed assessment + 15 min or 5 hours for a survey). The entry and exit points which call these functions are in the delivery bean. SessionUtil guarantees that the session will have the max of all concurrent threads taking assessments.

In terms of concurrent assessments in the same session, I tried to hash the stored timeout settings into the session but soon realized that the delivery bean object hashed to the same value for concurrent assessments in the same session. A bug will probably need to be created for this. If Samigo had separate delivery beans for two assessments in the same session, then I could have written a totally correct solution. As it stands, the solution works but could be enhanced a bit.

Note: after the assessment is completed the timeout is set to the value that the application (either Sakai or standalone) had it set to before beginning the assessment. This is where SessionUtil can set the timeout to the application value even if there is a concurrent assessment in progress. This is due to the fact that I can't hash on DeliveryBean.

Thanks,

-Jarrod
column75:
Here's what I've got so far:

Start assessment action:
1. if the assessment is timed and (timed + 15 min) > current session timeout
value then set session timeout to (timed + 15min)
2. if the assessment is not timed and 5 hours > current session timeout
value, then set session timeout to 5 hours

End assessment action:
1. if there are no other threads taking an assessment, set the the timeout
back to the original application value

As it stands, we cannot easily detect any other threads taking an assessment
because delivery bean is a session bound object.
Once this is changed we can store a hash map of (key,value)=(delivery bean's
hash value, timeout value for assessment) in session and on the 'end
assessment' action, check if the hash map is empty. If empty, then set the
timeout back to the application default.

timeout value for assessment (from above) = timed assessment + 15 or 5 hours
for untimed)

Thanks,

-Jarrod

column1: [SAK-2241] "Grade Override" not deleted when student is deleted, prevents editing of grade options
column6:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Set grade options to "letter grades with +/-"
2. Add an assignment or two, and go to the "Course Grade" screen (final row in the "overview")
3. Enter a "Grade overrides" using +/- values for one student
4. Delete the student that has an overridden grade
5. Go back to "Grade Options" and try to change the grade type to plain "letter grades". Click "save" at the bottom of the page

The result is an error that the grade overrides prevent changing the grade type, but returning to the override screen shows nothing because the student with the overridden grade is not shown.

See related bug SAK-2030 Closed

Deleted students either need to be permanently removed, completely ignored in all functions unless they are "undeleted", or still accessible through the user interface so that the data that is affecting other things can be changed.

column1: [SAK-2240] Patch for tests and quizzes reports the latest grade to gradebook, but claims to report best
column6:
One of our faculty considers this critical. If you take the same assessment more than once, tests and quizzes claims to report the best score to Gradebook. It claims this in Settings/Grading. There's no way to change the option, but if you look at a released test, it shows options Average and Best, with Bests chosen and the choice grayed out.

We think best actually makes sense.

The following patch, against 2090, will implement best. Note that the student will now see the latest in the Tests and Quizzes feedback, but the best in Gradebook. I believe that's right. After taking a test, the student will want to see feedback on their latest attempt. So Tests and Quizes shows that. But Gradebook will show the best result.

      • ./sam.hold/tool/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/assessment/facade/AssessmentGradingFacadeQueries.java Sun Oct 9 19:52:25 2005
      • ./sam/tool/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/assessment/facade/AssessmentGradingFacadeQueries.java Sun Oct 9 20:30:24 2005
        ***************
      • 281,286 ****
      • 281,320 ----
        }
        }

+ public AssessmentGradingData getBestGrade(AssessmentGradingIfc data) {
+ try {
+ Long publishedId = data.getPublishedAssessment().getPublishedAssessmentId();
+ String agentId = data.getAgentId();
+ Object[] objects = new Object[3];
+ objects[0] = publishedId;
+ objects[1] = agentId;
+ objects[2] = new Boolean(true);
+ Type[] types = new Type[3];
+ types[0] = Hibernate.LONG;
+ types[1] = Hibernate.STRING;
+ types[2] = Hibernate.BOOLEAN;
+ ArrayList scores = (ArrayList) getHibernateTemplate().find("from AssessmentGradingData a where a.publishedAssessment.publishedAssessmentId=? and a.agentId=? and a.forGrade=? order by submittedDate DESC", objects, types);
+ if (scores.isEmpty())
+ return null;
+
+ AssessmentGradingData best = null;
+ float bestvalue = 0.0f;
+
+ Iterator iter = scores.iterator();

column1: [SAK-34628] implement fuzzy numerical match in processing answers
column6:
This patch allows for fuzzy numerical matches in answers to fill in the blank questions. We have a user who is trying to use Sakai in a technical class. That inevitably involves numerical questions. There's no practical way to do this unless you can allow answers in varying formats (e.g. 1000 or 1E3) and with a range of acceptable values (to allow for slightly imprecision of numerical calculations).

The enclosed patch implements a syntax such as %F%100,10 for a value of 100 plus or minus 10. %F% is intended to be expandable to flags for other kinds of answer processing. F is, of course, for floating point.

This is with respect to revision 2090.

column1: [SAK-2232] tests and quizzes reports the latest grade to gradebook, but claims to report best
column6:
One of our faculty considers this critical. If you take the same assessment more than once, tests and quizzes claims to report the best score to Gradebook. It claims this in Settings/Grading. There's no way to change the option, but if you look at a released test, it shows options Average and Best, with Bests chosen and the choice grayed out.

We think best actually makes sense.

The following patch, against 2090, will implement best. Note that the student will now see the latest in the Tests and Quizzes feedback, but the best in Gradebook. I believe that's right. After taking a test, the student will want to see feedback on their latest attempt. So Tests and Quizes shows that. But Gradebook will show the best result.

column1: [SAK-2231] clarify getting and setting "current user" in the framework support
column6:
Getting the current user is done in two different ways; using the UsageSessionService (legacy, the old way) and using the SessionManager (kernel, new and approved way). The UsageSessionService has support for non-request threads to establish a user for further processing, but the kernel dpes not. This leads to confusion about how code should find the current user, and how in special cases it should change it.

Make the kernel method the prefered and most likely used way to get the current user; extend it so that a session is always delievered, even for non-request threads (this session will be temporary, good only for the thread execution), so that a current user can always be found using the current sessions's getUserId(), or a new manager level getCurrentSessionUserId() which is safe to call even if there's no current session (not going to happen, but lets be safe).

The UsagesSessionService is all about the database stored usage session record, to track the user's login session; usage events are linked to this record. It is not really about the in-memory session management; that's what the kernel' session API is for. Remove the support for thread-local non-request current user here. Remove or deprecate getSessionUserId().

Change as much code as possible to use the kernel instead of the UsageSessionService. Change the thread based code (maillet and others) to set the "user" via the session's setUserId() method instead of the UsageSessionService's method.

This is purely kernel clarification and refactoring; there's no functional change.
column10: clarify getting and setting "current user" in the framework support

column1: [SAK-2374] External Links take over iFrame
column6:
When following an external link on a Wiki page, the returned page occupies the whole of the iFrame. The only way back is the browser 'Back' button, which is discouraged in the rest of Sakai. This behaviour would be natural if the Wiki occupied the whole browser as most do, but in Sakai it is disconcerting.

Consider (a) handling external links as launching a new window or (b) retaining RWiki header or some other route back (sounds messy). Any other ideas?

column45: You are plotting with Marc!
column49:
Note that Safari is not currently a Sakai-compatible browser:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/ENC/Browser+Support

But hopefully its an easy fix...
column75:
Well, reporting bugs on non-supported browsers sort of defeats the whole point of having a suported browser list. I appreciate that we are getting coverage for this extra stuff, but when we add browsers to the mix that are not supported, everything that we assume about the client programming environment is up for grabs--DOM model, CSS2 support, editable HTML, etc.

If it doesn't work in either Firefox -or- Netscape 7.1 I will consider it a bug and try to get a fix in for this release.

If it is only a problem in non-supported browsers,and I find an easy fix, I will add it, but if it is not I will turn it into an enhancement request, lower it to trivial priority and defer it to the next release.
column80:
The described issue does not happen on Firefox or on Netscape 7.1, but does on unsupported browsers.

I don't have a clue as to how to make it work on either browser.
I think I would have to write a custom version of both the single and multiple choice pages to do so. It's not a good use of developer time just before a release.

I am especially concerned about IE 5.2 support, as it may not be possible to get JSF to work reliably there at all.

I am changing this to a feature request.

column1: [SAK-2228] Allow Session extensions for "long running" tools (e.g. Assignments, SAMigo)
column6:
For tools that require an extended usage period by the users where they may be active within the tool but have no client/server interaction for extended periods. We would like a way for the tool to put the SessionManager in a mode where the tool could somehow extend the Session duration.

Here is one of the common use cases:
1) The user begins a 2hr test or survey that is delivered on one page.
2) The user essentially works locally with no server interaction during these two hours.
3) After two hours, the user clicks submit and expects that all will proceed as expected.

Thanks, L

column1: [SAK-2227] Swallowed exception when writing to file system fails
column6:
Here is the scenario: ContentHosting is configured to store content in the file system rather than the database; e.g.:
bodyPath@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingService = /mnt/sakai
bodyVolumes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingService = a01,b01

If for some reason, the file system becomes unavailable to Sakai (e.g. nfs mounted file system is inaccessible) then Sakai must detect the error condition and display an appropriate error message to the user.

As the code stands right now (as of r2433) two very bad things happen:
1) Even though the file could not be created (FileNotFoundException) the row is still insterted into CONTENT_RESOURCE. This must be resolved. As it stands, the user thinks the file has been uploaded successfully when in fact it has not.

column1: [SAK-2226] Interface inconsistency, may lead to display of incorrect student grade
column6:
The instructor's "overview" page of the gradebook displays "Due Date", "Average", and "Points". The student view displays an additional letter grade from the "Grade Conversion" that is calculated according to the formula entered on the instructors "grade options" page. The instructor does not see this letter grade.

The assumption here is that the instructor has previously gone to the "grade options" to enter the correct grade conversion. If the instructor fails to do that, the "curve" may be incorrect and the students will see grades that have no bearing to how well they are actually doing in the course.

Since the instructor does not see the grade conversion on the main view or roster view of the gradebook, there is no feedback that the grade conversion is happening, or that it is correct or incorrect. There is no incentive to actually go to the "grade options" screen to do the right thing, the instructor must have prior knowledge of how the tool works in order to know to set it up correctly. Even if the instructor does visit the "grade options" screen it is not clear what the grade conversion is used for or where that displays, the instructor would actually have had to visit a course with a student account to understand this clearly.

The fix is simple: display the letter grade on the instructor's main "overview" page of the gradebook.
column10: Interface inconsistency, may lead to display of incorrect student grade
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
Thanks for pointing out this problem, Joseph. Unfortunately, your suggestion may not provide such a straightforward solution.

The "Overview" page you mention does not display the marks for an individual student's assignments. It gives you the entire class's average performance on the assignments. You probably meant to refer to the roster view in your suggestion. The roster view contains all of the scores for each of the students. There are two choices here, I think. We could add extra data to each score cell [9/10, A-]or provide a cumulative calculated grade for all assignments.

The first choice was rejected by the design team because it made for a lot of clutter. The latter option was not considered viable because we didn't have time to build in finer grained instructor control over the accuracy of the cumulative course grade at any point in time. Another feature that we had to scrap was a view of individual students (linked to from the roster names) that would have given instructors the same data the students themselves see. There are existing designs for both of these potential solutions.

Do you have any other suggestions?
column45:
Of course your right about the roster page vs the overview page.

An alternative approach is to set the default grade conversion to null, then change the student display to show nothing until the instructor fills in the grade conversion. This is probably a better approach in the long run, because it avoids the situation of the technology "deciding" how a course will be graded (which is how some faculty I work with are likely to see it).

I still think there needs to be some more apparent indicator either on the overview page or the roster page that the grade conversion is being displayed to the student - the equivalent of the "student view" in tests and quizzes, or maybe just an "on/off" indicator.
column49: Oliver, is this issue scheduled to be addressed for 2.1.0, or should it become a feature request? Thanks.
column75: This issue involves other design decisions that have not yet been made. I am reluctant to turn the solution to what was a bad UI choice on our part into a feature request, but we will not fix the problem for 2.1. Up to you, Peter.
column80:
Let me reiterate, in some cases Sakai is doing an incorrect calculation on student grades and displaying an incorrect grade to students. The "bad UI" choice is the cause, but the results are far from a UI issue.

This is not a feature request, it is a bug. And while it may not be "major" or "critical" from a programmer's standpoint, try telling faculty that you have a nice little course management system for them to use that may report incorrect grades unless they are careful and you'll get another definition of "major".
column84: It has remained a bug. Regretably, we won't be able to fix it for 2.1.
column88:
We will implement a partial fix to mitigate this problem for 2.1.

The Overview page will feature a grade option status read out and link to the grade options page. The 3 messages being considered are

Students can see their assignment scores and grades, but not their course grade (as letter grade). Change these settings.

or

Students can see their assignment scores and grades and course grade (as Pass/Fail).Change these settings.

or

Students can not see their assignment scores and grades or course grade Change these settings.
column92:
The final UI details have been worked out for the Grade Options status message. It will appear above the current instructional text in the following variations:

Students can see their assignment scores and grades, but not their course grades (as grade type). Change Grade Options.

or

Students can see their assignment scores and grades and course grades (as grade type).Change Grade Options.

or

Students can not see their assignment scores and grades or course grades Change Grade Options.
column96: The proposed UI has some issues which either have to be worked out quickly or postponed to post-2.1.
column100:
I've checked in Ben's suggested format for displaying current grade options on the Overview page.

The following are the message formats I used, all followed by the linked text "Change grade options.":

  • Students can see their assignment scores and grades (as Letter Grades with +/-), but not their course grade.
  • Students can see their course grade (as Letter Grades with +/-), but not their assignment scores and grades.
  • Students can see their assignment scores and grades and course grade (as Letter Grades with +/-).
  • Students can not see their assignment scores and grades or course grade.

Only instructors (or, more exactly, only people who can edit assignments) are shown this message.

We should probably also improve the "Display assignment grades to students" option to make its result clearer. I'll wait for final word from you or Ben on that.

column1: [SAK-2223] Should allow UserDirectoryProvider to indicate if it is to be consulted before or after Sakai's internal tables
column6:
In the file:

sakai/legacy/component/src/java/org/sakaiproject/component/legacy/user/BaseUserDirectoryService.java

In method authenticate (line 959) we need to add the capability for the provider (if it exists) to determine the order that the Sakai internal structures and the provider are checked.

The current code always checks the local table and then only calls the provider if the user does not exist or fails a password check locally.

A method should be added to the UserDirectoryProvider called

boolean providerFirst()

Which the provider can return "true" if the privoder wants to be called first. "false" retains the current behavior.

This also requires changing the existing providers (both the examples, and any providers developed in the field). But the change is trivial - simply returning false in the method causes the behavior to comtinue unchanged.
column10: Should allow UserDirectoryProvider to indicate if it is to be consulted before or after Sakai's internal tables

This bug indicates that in this particular case, the schedule tool is not correctly truncating the HTML-formatted text.

Its probably just blindly truncating it to 50 characters - which as you pointed out, is incorrect.

See the synoptic announcement tool for an example of the right way to use the FormattedText class to solve this bug.

column1: [SAK-2217] Email digest scheduling
column6: Abililty for worksite maintainer to schedule what time an email archive digest is sent to users.
column10: Email digest scheduling
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: David, could you provide some use cases for this feature? Thanks.
column45: Might also want to let individual users set the time in their profiles, and override site settings. Could be useful in project sites where members are spread around the world and want read their digests over breakfast at different times.
column49: The idea of letting individual users change digest times might be fine, but mostly our instructors would like to have control over what time the digest is sent to students. For instance, if an instructor sends out a message saying "bring these materials to class tomorrow" and the digest doesn't go out until Midnight, then a student probably won't see the message until morning and will miss vital instructions.
column75:
In that case (vital instructions), the notification should be sent with the "Email Notification - High" option (as an announcement that is), which will get sent out immediately rather than digested.

There might be a case for the email archive to check the message priority field and behave appropriately too.

In general though this brings up an interesting question which we've been thinking about in the context of SMS notifications (mobile/GSM text messages) - should message options be under the control of the recipient or the sender?
column80: A little of both. As far as choosing individual messages vs. batch, the recipient should have that option. But ultimately the sender is making the message available at the time of their choosing and at whatever level of importance they find appropriate. I don't really see a point in letting a recipient choose their digest time since they can do so by simply checking their email when they want to.
column84: As with most things in Sakai the goal is to support a wide variety of audiences, so hopefully the question becomes somewhat moot regarding putting message options under control of the recipient or sender, if the policy is configurable. A Sakai system being used exclusively for CMS might want to let the Instructors or Campus policy have the ultimate say-so in whether or not individuals can affect digest delivery, whereas a Sakai system being used to support globaly distrubted research collaborations might want to let end-users have the ultimate say-so on digest delivery so they can match their daily work habits in their local timezone.
column88:
I know this is an old thread, but in case someone else is looking into this:

One possible approach, with the given code in Sakai, is to have a standard time for restarting your server and setting the email.digest.start.delay (sakai.property) to correspond with the preferred time for your digest. Obviously, if you do a restart at a different time you will have a different digest time and may get a few upset users.
column92:
Right, I'd responded on the dev list a few years ago about this and how you could put in an function to dynamically calculate the delay based on what time you wanted it to start.

However this doesn't solve the problem of user specific delays, which I think is what this was asking for. It would be nice if it had a timer actually checked preferences for users, and this timer (BaseDigestService) checked these preferences. Would have to make sure that check has good performance (all defined custom times cached). I'm not sure how much interest there is in this anyway.

===========-=
Just as a followup, there is a property: email.digest.start.delay
(seconds default 300) which you could 'kind of' rig to get the start
time you desire. It's the number of seconds that the server starts up,
but you'd have to modify it every time in the current setup
unfortunately.

The best way would be if you had a set restart time (Like your servers
restarted a few times a week at 5AM to clean out the session cache,
etc.) and you knew when you wanted to send it, that might fulfill your
needs without having to recode anything.

Or if you're not sure when you'll start up but you'll know it'll be
before 5PM, you can write some shell script in bash (have an original
sakai.properties file that you'll append to)

cp sakai.properties.original sakai.properties
echo `date +%s -d '5PM'` - `date +%s` | xargs -I{} echo "a={};if
(a<0)a=a+(60*60*24);a" | bc | xargs echo email.digest.start.delay= >>
sakai.properties

(That extra bit in the middle fixes for negative time by waiting until tomorrow)

It can do whatever you want it to do though though in the code.

column1: [SAK-2215] questions imported from qp should not be editable by other users
column6:
See linked issue SAK-2214 Closed .

If more than one user has the maintain role in a site, they should be able to edit questions in each others' assessments only if the questions are not drawn from question pools. If the question came from someone else's question pool, the user trying to edit it should get a warning message. (Right now Samigo
just throws an exception.)

Steps to reproduce:

1. Log in as user #1. Go to a site in which #1 has the maintain role.
2. In the site, go to T&Q and create an assessment. Import a question from a question pool into the assessment, and save it.
3. Go to the Site Info tool and grant user #2 the maintain role in the site. Log out.
4. Log in as user #2 and go to the site, then T&Q. You have the maintain role now, so you can view the new assessment.
5. Modify the question that user #1 imported and click save.
6. Boom.

What should happen is that Samigo should check whether the question was imported from a question pool or created from scratch. If the question was created from scratch, user #2 should be able to edit it. If the question came from a question pool, #2 should get a warning message.
column10: questions imported from qp should not be editable by other users
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: Just to clarify the rule we used to implement this: When you copy a question from a pool to an assessment, the question is not linked to the pool. It's a brand new question. When you create a question in an assessment and assign it to a pool then the item is linked to the pool.
column45: Hmmm. That's not how I understood what Marc said. Can we get him to clarify?
column49: Lydia is correct. If a question has been copied (once called imported) into an assessment then it's a new question and anyone with maintain should be able to edit it.
column75: See bug SAK-2214 Closed . Now all users with 'maintain' access can modify questions in an assessment, regarless if they are are linked to a pool or not. see svn commit for SAK-2214 Closed .

column1: [SAK-2214] editing someone else's question throws exception
column6:
observed in nightly qa oracle instance.

If more than one user has the maintain role in a site, they should be able to edit questions in each others' assessments as long as the questions are not drawn from question pools. Right now Samigo throws an exception if you try that. (see attached).

Steps to reproduce:

1. Log in as user #1. Go to a site in which #1 has the maintain role.
2. In the site, go to T&Q and create an assessment. Create a new question, any type, to go in the assessment. (Don't save it to a question pool.)
3. Go to the Site Info tool and grant user #2 the maintain role in the site. Log out.
4. Log in as user #2 and go to the site, then T&Q. You have the maintain role now, so you can view the new assessment.
5. Modify the question that user #1 created and click save.
6. Boom.

What should happen is that Samigo should check whether the question was imported from a question pool or created from scratch. If the question was created from scratch, user #2 should be able to edit it. (If the question came from a question pool, #2 should get a warning message - see linked issue).
column10: editing someone else's question throws exception
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: What are the rules?
column45:
Questions within an assessment should be editable by anyone with the maintain role. I know, people modify other people's items, is a problem, but only creators being able to edit questions in an assessment is a bigger problem.

Now that the Sakai framework supports groups (2.1), we can implement permissions for QP questions and perhaps rethink the workflow.

column1: [SAK-2213] Gradebook missing doctype and namespace declaration
column6:
Sorry not to mention this before. The markup produced by gradebook is missing the doctype and namespace declaration.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">

<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" lang="en" xml:lang="en">

This is not just academic, without it there is no guarantee that the user agents will operate in standards compliance mode - we cannot fix rendering bugs with assurance.
column10: Gradebook missing doctype and namespace declaration
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41: Since the gradebook is fully internationalized, are the lang="en" and xml:lang="en" attributes necessary/correct?
column45:
You know, as I was posting the Jira I thought about that, but concluded it was a separate issue altogether. The namespace declaration is needed, but the lang and xml:lang attributes should be parametrized and obey locale settings - you are quite right.

Excuse my ignorance - is there not some JSF tag that should be taking care of this already? And taking care of the doctype as well? Should there not be one? I notice Samigo is getting by with <f:verbatim /> and the needed doctype and namespace declaration on each JSP literally. This seems like an excellent place to modularize a bit, no? And not just for human language reasons, but markup language as well. It would make switching to XHTML strict easier, or providing wml to wml user agents, if that is something we want to do.

Should this JIRA be retargetted?
column49:
> Should this JIRA be retargetted?

Well, it does look as if it should be copied-and-pasted a few times. For the Sakai-embedded version of the Gradebook, I just mimicked what I found in the existing Sakai tools, which are kind of short on DOCTYPE / xmlns declarations.

I agree that it would be nice to have this get done at the presentation framework level. But the relevant part of the Gradebook is centralized via JSP "prelude" and "coda" features – I should only have to change two files.

I'd like to leave out the "lang" and "xml:lang" attributes for now, though, since my understanding is that JSF is supposed to take care of inserting localization parameters:

http://blog.sun.com/roller/page/edburns/20041214#the_basics_of_rendering_xhtml
column75:
OK....looks like we will have to leave out the lang attribute:

https://javaserverfaces.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=78
column80: Checked in as revision 2479.

column1: [SAK-2212] User Preferences should allow selection of user-local time zone
column6: The TimeService provides support for both GMT and local timezones. Currently the local timezone is set to the default for a server location. However, for distributed collaboration eResearch groups, different users are often located in different timezones. This proposal provides support for defining a TimeZone as a user preference, and returning time relative to a users local timezone from the TimeService.

2. User A: Change timezone
3. User A: Add chat message – verify time is correct for specified timezone
4. User A: Add discusssion message – verify time is correct for specified timezone
5. User A: Add schedule event – verify time is correct for specified timezone
6. User A: Verify correct timezone in schedule's daily, weekly, activity details, list of activities, print activity
7. User A: Send email and verify correct timezone representation in email tool

8. Repeat steps 1-7 for user B

column41:
Spec:

This function will allow a authzd user to change the ownership and/or group of a rwiki document within a space.

Questions:

  1. Who can do this (define authzd)
  2. Which groups can the change to
  3. Which owners can they change to

Who can do it.

  1. The owner of the document
  2. Any user with rwiki.admin in the current realm (ie group/worksite/etc, need to check with Sections imp in 2.1)
  3. Any user with rwiki.superadmin

Which owners can they change to

  1. anyone (input text box to accept the userid)

Which groups can the change to

  1. Any site that they are a member of presented as a drop down. (come from site lookup RealmService?)

Estimated 2 days dev time

(I hope this supports markup )

column1: [SAK-2203] link to archived message in email messages themselves
column6: Currently email messages sent via Sakai store server-side the attachments and provide links to them in a footer to the message content. Additionally, once email archives are hyperlinkable SAK-2201 Closed , the messages should include a link to the server-side representation of the message. (This allows a user to jump right into Sakai in the context of that message, which provides for re-establishing thread context in the case of a message later found in isolation (the user deleted the rest of the thread in her email client)). Users entitled to see the email archive can re-establish context when a message is forwarded out of context to them. And the link can be used in the context of websites and wiki pages (a redactor receiving an email and extracting its content for a webpage can include a link to the message on which the webpage update is based).

column1: [SAK-2201] Hyperlinking into email archives
column6:
The email archive tool should be able to handle a URL linking directly to a particular archived email. This would allow it to be used in the way that the static HTML archives produced by tools like Pipermail can be used - I can send you a link to a relevant email or thread on the cas@tp CAS discussion list, for example.

In the case of email archives that are not publicly viewable, the URL should require the user to be logged in or to login before resolving to the message.

This requirement comes from discussion in the Integration DG.

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/x/Rh4

column41:
This also affects users who are trying to open multiple email archive messages in different tabs or windows. The more traffic a site generates, the more frustrating it is to have to return to the list each time you read a message rather than using the list as a basis to open a series of messages you can quickly scan through for relevance.

On a slightly different tack it would also be nice to include message x of y text when viewing a message.

I have found it as a problem in local installs of 2.1.1 and 2.2.1 as well as 2.2.2 collab.

column1: [SAK-2200] Random draw parts and review list
column6:
Random draw assessment parts look okay in delivery and when you view the feedback in the review list as a student. But when you view the statistics in the review list, all questions from the source pool are included.

Is this the right behavior? It means that after taking a test with a random draw part, you can go back and see every possible question you could have been asked, and that other students might be asked. (Fortunately you can't see the answers).

Something for Marc to decide.

column1: [SAK-2198] RSS view on email archive
column6:
The email archive tool should provide an RSS view on the archive, highlighting the most recent posts. This adds the capability of following the cutting edge in an RSS reader, while relying upon Sakai email archives to store the archive more permanently (doesn't fill the user's inbox). Provides nice website integration opportunities. Note that such a feed would be much more valuable if each item could provide a hyperlink to the message in the context of the Sakai email archive.

In the case where authentication is required to see the email archive, there is a problem to be solved here in terms of how to provide end users with URLs that will work in their RSS readers of choice. One solution is to generate ad-hoc large unique identifiers suitable for use as keys and expose RSS URLs accepting these keys only to access the RSS feed (without granting more general access to Sakai). In the case of publicly accessible email archives this wrinkle isn't required.

This RFE comes from discussion in the Integration DG.
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=7750
column10: RSS view on email archive
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

That is: for a particular site I would like to receive individual emails, but for another site i can live with one summary email per day.

column1: [SAK-2190] Import/export: survey question problems
column6:
(observed in nightly oracle and hsql instances)

I created an assessment with all survey questions, one of each type, exported it from mysql, and then imported it to both oracle and hsqldb. (exported xml is attached.)

The good news is that no text at all got lost. However, some fields got added. A Rationale text box got added to every question in delivery, even though survey questions don't have a rationale option. And a blank selection-level feedback field got added for every answer choice.

I guess this isn't really a major bug, since the extra rationale field adds functionality rather than takes it away. But it will still make survey-givers unhappy.
column10: Import/export: survey question problems

column41: The UI for MCSC does double duty for surveys. For some reason, the fields are turned on when imported, however, that doesn't really matter. What does matter is in delivery, where an unwanted rationale is required (or item level feedback) or in authoring, where you have no way of turning off these fields. I added a fix to suppress that behavior.
column45:

column1: [SAK-2188] Exceptions from ResourcesAction
column6:
This is reported for Falcon incident IM274750. My description -
If you click on "Show other sites" to expand other sits' resources for attachments through file-picker (I tested with Syllabus and Announcements, they behave the same). Then click on one of the links with other sites' name (assume this site has some file resources). This site will jump to the first position in the resources list. If you click on the same sites' name link again, it will give out a blank page. Exceptions are:
java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.sakaiproject.tool.content.ResourcesAction.getCollectionPath(ResourcesAction.java:7169)
at org.sakaiproject.tool.content.ResourcesAction.buildSelectAttachmentContext(ResourcesAction.java:960)
at org.sakaiproject.tool.content.ResourcesAction.buildHelperContext(ResourcesAction.java:879)
at org.sakaiproject.tool.announcement.AnnouncementAction.buildMainPanelContext(AnnouncementAction.java:730)......

The null pointer comes from navRoot. If we have some "if" clause to handle the null navRoot, it will solve the problem. I found the same thing has to do for "id" in line 7177 too.

column45: Many links are now broken in the list mode of the attachment picker. Both navigation and selection.
column49: There were two problems causing this. column1: [SAK-2183] Performance on Scores page
column6:
The Performance on Scores page is slow, especially when there are a lot of responses.
This is also related to SAK-1673 Closed
column10: Performance on Scores page
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
The scores page is slow for three reasons.

1) The initial data pull is massive. 14 tables in 16 joins. these queries are executed many many times. A lazy load or two might speed this up significantly. Some indexes might help as well.
2) The user processing loop grabs the AuthzGroup of the realm for each user. This operation was ~1 second per. A map of the users and roles should be pulled once instead of the the authzgroup per user.
3) The loading of the page on the client is slow because each wysiwyg textarea imports the javascript files. Browsers may be pulling the javascripts each time thus slowing the page download. the wysiwyg editor should put an indicator into the request or into the top level component of the page that signals that the javascript files have been placed. when present, the tag shouldn't render the javascript links. This is a different bug though.
column45: Lydia, will this issue be addresssed for 2.1.0? Thanks.
column49: Ed can you take a look at the wywisyg editor issue? (#3 above)
column75: Brad has addressed #2.
column80:
OK. We still need someone to look at the queries.

However, as I recall, we are not supposed to have a table full of wysiwyg editors for this page as per the new specs. The comments were to be textareas, and my preliminary research indicates somebody put them back in after they were taken out.

Investigating further....
column84:
OK. It looks like this bug was filed before the wysiwyg editors were taken out of all the jsf evaluation pages except single student score--which would not be a performance problem.
The new mockups use bare HTML textarea inputs, which are very efficient.

Daisy will be working on further optimization in the database queries.

column1: [SAK-2182] Remember Number of Items User Decides to Display in a List View
column6:
The page widget should remember the user's last setting for a paticular tool and use that setting the next time the user visits it (yes, across sessions). We've taken a guess at a meaningful default but there are so many factors involved in the setting that an individual user is the best judge of this. Because it's an easy change for the user we don't want to force them to choose a preference. Instead remember what they had it set to last time. They'll be using their preferred viewing for that particular tool most of the time so it will be set up the way they want it the next time they visit. If they were doing a less common task that required a different than normal setting than it just takes a change of the dropdown to fix it. Notice the less common here. It is a real pain if they have to change the setting everytime they visit the page. Here and there when they were doing an infrequent task is OK.

_____________________________________
Original Description:

On all tools the view to ¿Show 20¿ ect should initially display all items, with the user being able to set the view they would like to see.
column10: Remember Number of Items User Decides to Display in a List View
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
One might argue for a larger number being the default across tools, however, show all is likely to get the user in trouble. For example, the list of participants in a large lecture might contain 700 students, which also means the Drop Box list and viewing Assignments by Student would also be 700 long and so on; the list of sites (or most other items) in any of the admin interfaces on a production system easily reaches the thousands;

If a user is working with a long list, then it often takes a long time for the list to be generated and displayed. That means the user can be left sitting at an inteface with no list and no indication that one is being worked on; though, an in-progress indicator of some type might help alleviate that part of the problem.
column45: I'd like to see the default number to display be a user-configurable preference. One that is remembered from session to session.
column49:
I don't think a user even needs to configure this. A common interaction is to remember the user's last choice (from session to session). That way their preference is typically set for them from session to session, they haven't had to configure anything (or know that you can) and if they do happen to look at a different view infrequently, then they simply change it back to the default and it will again be back there for them.

I just met with an instructor today who brought this up as one of his top frustrations with bSpace. It may be a minor annoyance but it happens several times in almost all visits. He like to see all students in the gradebook which defaults to 20 I think. He like chat to always show the time. He has to change this on every visit too.

The cases where I'd consider View_right useful are for:

  • to provide a simple content navigation structure / index / site map for the wiki

or

column1: [SAK-2164] Shouldn't allow empty fill-in-blank answers
column6:
It's currently possible to create a fill in the blank question with nothing in the blank, or nothing but spaces. Example:

Cows go

{moo}

and rocks go {}.

If there's nothing between the brackets, when you modify the saved question the word "null" will appear there and end up as the answer key. If there's one or more spaces between the brackets, those are considered the answer.

What should happen instead: When you save a FIB question, Samigo should check that there is at least one non-space character between each set of curly braces. If there isn't, the user should get a validation error similar to the unmatched-brackets one, and the question should not be created. How about:

Answers must contain at least one non-space character.
column10: Shouldn't allow empty fill-in-blank answers

column41: Huong, thanks for pointing this out, and here is a bug for you

Huong

On the mysql and oracle instances I do get a warning message when I try to create one, but it's the wrong warning. It says "please make sure your curly brackets match". Instead, we need the "each answer must contain at least one non-space character" warning.

column1: [SAK-2160] Gradebook AuthZ filter not working
column6:
Verified below report on UCB's 2.0 QA instance.

We found a security related bug yesterday in Assignments, and it appears to exist in Gradebook and Syllabus as well. Very obscure, and hard to see how a student could uncover it, but it's there nonetheless, and one of our QA folks thought of it, so... It allows students to change their grade in Assignment or Gradebook, or edit a Syllabus item. A student could I suppose install Sakai themselves, and in fooling around discover a back door to enabling them to get to otherwise unpermitted edit pages.

They can do this by pasting in the equivalent of the instructor's URL to the grade page or syllabus edit page.

So as an instructor, go to the Gradebook, and right click over one of the assignments in the list and save the URL.
Logout, and log back in with a student account. Paste the URL in and you can get to where you can change grades.

Someone would have to know the format of the URL etc., so not likely. You'd have to be an instructor to get it.
https://ctools.umich.edu/portal/tool/35512628-bb7e-4218-804b-371268b3ba9d/overview#
But if someone installed their own private Sakai, and was fooling around, they might come across it, and the next day it's on a Sakai hack website, and the next day students everywhere just got smarter.

Zhen just checked in a fix (2156) to the problem in assignments. Perhaps she can provide add'l info if needed. There is talk of a 2.0.1 'official' patch, w/ notification sent to contacts only of those running pilots to try to keep knowledge of the problem contained.

John
column10: Gradebook AuthZ filter not working
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
The Gradebook has authz filters to prevent just this problem, but at some point the web.xml for the Sakai build drifted away from reality so that the filters were no longer being called.

This is one of the big gaps in our automatic testing. JUnit can test the authz routines, but we can't check that the actual deployment will be calling them. We need to make sure that it becomes an annoying part of the QA testers' routine.

Checked in the fix as Revision 2159.

It's a simple one, and so I'll generate patches for 2.01 and 2.0 and attach them to this bug report.

column1: [SAK-2158] Gradebook roster search/navigation interaction produces error
column6:
If a search term (name or SID) has been entered in the grading table/roster and the user clicks either of the forward navigation arrows, the result is a blank iframe and background error.

Clicking the back arrow filters the roster, ignoring the user's navigation request. This behavior was not explicitly specified and will likely be changed so that the search term is ignored. Resolution of the bug should ensure that the behavior of the forward arrows matches the back arrows'.

See also:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=7808
column10: Gradebook roster search/navigation interaction produces error
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column41:
Given the scattered order in which JSF delivers its mixed message in this ambiguous situation, it's easier to resolve it by always doing what's specified in the search box, no matter which navigation button the user clicked.

Oliver has OK-ed that change of plan, and I checked in the fix as revision 3346.

column1: [SAK-2143] Schedule Tool - add Email Notification option
column6: Instructors have requested the Email notification option for the Schedule Tool. When someone creates a schedule event there should be an optional "send notification" option. Such an email could either be sent as the event is created, or it could be sent as a "reminder" email at some specified time prior to the start of an event.
column10: Schedule Tool - add Email Notification option
column19: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
column41:
We have also received requests from both students and faculty to have the calendar tool send reminders. This would require the addition of a field for when the notification should be sent. It's slightly different from the e-mail notification method used by other tools in that it delays the notification, but I think this would serve the same purpose (just set the notification time to "now").

From faculty:
"It would be nice to have extended functionality for the
schedule/calendar function: one should be able to set a reminder for
each event. More precisely, one should be able to specify what kind of
reminder is needed (email to the listserv, pop-up message on the screen,
...) and the time (days, hours or minutes before the event)."

From a student:
"I would like to suggest a warning system on the calendar. Say for
instance a group sets up a meeting, the calendar can then remind the users
of the site that the meeting is up and coming. This could also help for
deadlines and the like"
column45:
On Sep 8, 2007, at 9:56 PM, Lance Speelmon wrote:

Sakai now has a general capability to implement such a feature. See: org.sakaiproject.api.app.scheduler
.ScheduledInvocationManager. I believe Announcements was enhanced to send delayed notifications. Best, L
column49:

column75:
This request is common here at Oxford too.

If the facility were just the same as for resources, ie, send a note when an event is created or changed, that would probably satisfy most people.
column80: Problem also reported frequently here at Delaware. The fact that Schedule does not have an email notification option is inconsistent with other tools.
column84: Also a concern here in San Diego COE.
column88: CLE team bulk inactive issues cleanup - if this is important then reopen or create a new issue
column92:
This seems like a relatively reasonable (and not uncommon) request, and particularly because Sign-up has email notification, I'm surprised that it hasn't been addressed or discussed recently. Reopening for this reason.

Here's the use case presented to us:

  • Instructor has a monthly quiz and she wants to publish each month's quiz in advance for the entire semester.
  • She wants to notify students via email the day before it becomes available, but samigo notifications only send on publish.
  • She wants to add a recurring event in Calendar that will send notification.
  • Sign-up tool cannot be used as a workaround for this because she would have to add each student individually to the event when signing them up. Additionally, this quiz is mandatory, not something they should sign up for.

Can the existing notification code in Sign-up be leveraged to add an option in Calendar Notify site members via email a day before the event, or something similar?

column1: [SAK-2141] Possibility of student modifying their assignment grades
column6:
There is a way that a student can access their instructor's 'grade' view and modify grades, or modify an assignment. It is an obscure way, but nevertheless possible.

What I did is to right-click on an assignment and chose 'send link'. This gave me the entire URL of the assignment. This is an example:
https://testctools.ds.itd.umich.edu/portal/tool/7652851f-3781-49d5-80a3-e7195ca8849e?sakai_action=doView_submission&panel=Main&assignmentReference=/assignment/a/260472a9-6bd4-4da6-00e5-685465274d24/d520ffaf-55cb-4b00-0025-6af47e886712

I logged in as the instructor of that same site and opened up the URL for the 'grade' link of that same assignment. This is the link I got:
https://testctools.ds.itd.umich.edu/portal/tool/7652851f-3781-49d5-80a3-e7195ca8849e?sakai_action=doGrade_assignment&panel=Main&assignmentId=/assignment/a/260472a9-6bd4-4da6-00e5-685465274d24/d520ffaf-55cb-4b00-0025-6af47e886712

If you are a student in the class and type in the last URL, then you get the same access as the instructor's grade option. You can change grades and such.

There isn't a lot of differences between the two links above:
change doView_submission to doGrade_assignment and Reference to Id

Student might learn of the structure of the links by creating a site themselves, viewing the links and trying it themselves.
